intro: Homalocephala parryi, commonly known as the Parry's ghostflower, is a rare and elusive flowering plant native to the high elevations of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, delicate flowers. The plant thrives in rocky, arid environments and is adapted to withstand extreme temperature fluctuations and limited water availability. Due to its habitat specificity and low population numbers, it is considered a vulnerable species. Its unique morphology and ecological niche make it an important subject for botanical research and conservation efforts.
